prop.head.headtext: Remedies for Breach of Confidential Business Information
Special Considerations with Regard to Injunctions

para.paratext: Injunctions are not usually granted to enforce performance under an employment contract if this will amount to indirect specific performance of an employment contract, if to do so would perpetuate a relationship based on mutual trust and confidence, or where the applicant is seeking to enforce an unreasonable restraint of trade.[1] However, the courts may force an employee to cease working for a competitor under the following circumstances:
There is no unreasonable restraint of trade (i.e., the respondent would not be forced to continue the relationship with the moving party or remain idle).[2]
The injunction would not force the parties to perpetuate a relationship based on mutual trust and confidence which has ceased to exist.
The injunction would not amount to the indirect specific performance of a contract for personal services.

However, such an injunction should be obtained on notice. In Robert Half Canada Inc. v. Jeewan,[3] the court refused to continue an injunction as a sanction to the party that moved for an injunction without notice.
Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc. v. Nelson, [1937] 1 K.B. 209.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc. v. Nelson, [1937] 1 K.B. 209; Ehrman v. Bartholomew, [1898] 1 Ch. 671; Page One Records Ltd. v. Britton, [1968] 1 W.L.R. 157 (Ch.). See also Warren v. Mendy, [1989] 1 W.L.R. 853 (C.A.).
Robert Half Canada Inc. v. Jeewan (2004), 33 C.C.E.L. (3d) 302, 49 C.P.C. (5th) 270 (Ont. S.C.J.).
